Comment: I suppose it depends on what your starting period is. If you date them from the end of the 2008-09 recession, a logical starting point, there have been three hikes in the overnight rate and two declines, as you say, 1/4 percentage point each time. That's five changes in seven and a half years. So that's about one 25-basis-point change every 18 months, a frequency that decreases with every month that our central bank keeps the overnight rate where it is.

Comment: The article barely mentions local broadcast TV. With an inexpensive "leaf" antenna with an amplifier, I get 12 channels. I stream Netflix and Amazon. Might consider Hulu if they have a discount deal.

Comment: Are you attempting to convince us that a hurricane, where most of the damage is done by high sustained winds, flying debris and flooding, will not impact a solar farm covering many acres or windmills which are hundreds of feet tall? Tell me, what may be repaired more quickly, a snapped power pole or a solar panel? A downed power line or a destroyed windmill blade? A power line hung from a pole or one submerged in a flooded utility tunnel? We have the system we have because it is the most productive for smallest cost. At some point wind and solar may become more reliable and less expensive, but we are not yet at that point, are we. When it is reached, the same economic laws which replaced horse drawn carriages with automobiles will replace our current power grid.

Comment: It is really simple.  The athletic department should support academic success.  As far as that goes, the ski team has always been one of the jewels of the athletic department, but even the ski team has a travel budget that makes little sense.  Can you imagine what an impressive intramural program could be had for 25% of the athletic department budget?  We would have club teams with coaches.  We would have tourna,nets between the best UAA and UAF basketball teams.  We would train professional quality referees and we would have workshops for intramural coaches.

It could be a revolutionary awesome program.  Instead we hand out scholarships to a bunch of Canucks.  I love the boys, and I love watching the Nanooks beat the Seawolves, but we have lost sight on the point of the whole thing.

A travel budget is not needed to support elite skiers in Alaska.  They are already where they need to be.  Keep the program and tell the NCAA to get wet.  That's my solution.

Sessions conveniently left out that the House of Representatives passed the Dream Act and that fifty-five out of one hundred U.S. Senators supported it.

Comment: It is yet another wake up call. I live in California, 40 or so miles from the beach, but we all know the storm drains go to the ocean. But all this crap from 7 billion people, and especially those of us at the coasts, isn't just going to biodegrade away.  We just banned plastic bags here in California for grocery purchases. It is a hassle to bring a bag to the store, but we get by, and sometimes I use no bag at all.  There are ways our civilization can change to solve or at least reduce these problems.

Apostle John is a possible candidate for the beloved, but John is not named as someone specifically "loved" by Jesus, as is Lazarus. Comment: One additional thought--my children learn about biology, literature, grammar, chemistry, history, arts, etc. in school. I choose to engage them on those subjects as well because they all interest me. Just because they are learning or being taught something at school does not mean that I won't insert myself into the mix. Sometimes, I have expertise that exceeds the teachers at school, and sometimes I disagree with the way they frame information. But I think even those moments provide learning opportunities and the chance to encourage critical thinking among my children. My goal is that they become independent thinkers and responsible adults willing to own the consequences of the choices they make in life, even when they choose to disagree with me, an inevitable outcome, but one I welcome all the same. Their choices and their lives are ultimately their own, and I didn't wait until they were 18 to start giving them choices. My children are not "mine"; they are beings unto themselves.

Comment: They're irrelevant. They left little mark, and they're all dead, as we will be, too. Native groups in the Americas came here across the Bering Strait and by raft across the Pacific. They wandered, they fought, they despoiled areas and then nomadically moved on. They didn't record their own history or have common written or spoken languages, while both were developing elsewhere on the Globe. We're all humans. Our tribe is irrelevant. What matters is what we create for our successors and how we treat those in our midst. It's time for the myths of the past to be put to bed. Science tells us how plants and trees grow, and it's not because some slippery shaman whispered into the ground. Some animals have vocabularies, some day we will know what they are saying. Then we can say 'Rex, you're a good boy' and it will be translated into dogese and Rex will smile and tell you he's hungry. Comment: Statutes of limitation have a legitimate purpose in many situations, but you have to distinguish between criminal matters and civil claims for damages. In Australia, we have never had statutes of limitation for serious crimes, and I was surprised to learn that some jurisdictions in the United States and Europe do have them.  In the case of civil claims for damages, limitations statutes create certainty for business planning, so that after 6 years in Australia, you cannot sue for tort or breach of contract. They encourage claimants to sue quickly, and recognise the possibility that with the passage of time memories fade and evidence will disappear. Such statutes can operate unfairly where the damage does not appear until after the 6 years has passed. For that reason, in Australia, courts can extend the period in the case of mesothelioma as well as child sexual abuse. They are unfair in the case of child sexual abuse and should be changed where they exist.

Comment: I have camped out in McCarthy several times this time of year in mid-August. The bears are all over eating the soapberries. The residents are well armed and gun shots to scare off the bears are heard anytime day or night. I have been close to mom and cubs both black bears and grizzly bears. There are many single bears of both species an one amazing bear to us was a large cinnamon black bear that looked like a big grizzly. Hiking at that time of year requires a gun and a can of bear spray an keep them handy.  The weather in that area is chaotic, you start out with a t-shirt on a sunny day and very rapidly a storm will move in suddenly and you will get drenched with rain, which happened to me once, leading to a long chilly hike back to the camp site. It is also cold there this time of year an can easily have freezing temps at night. There is local cell service and that is sketchy. A skilled outdoors person is required to explore this wilderness area. I hope he is taking his time, is all.

UBI does not pay people not to work. It supplements income to guarantee security and inject market confidence.

Comment: Trades journeymen have always held the engineers in contempt. Nothing new there. Our roads from the valley to the coast all run mostly through valleys and over passes to another valley. For one thing, that's where the people live. For another thing those are well-defined routes with relatively flat land. Bypassing the meanderings of the valleys requires massive cut-and-fill operations including blasting and grading. The tough basalt of Mary Mountain and other high peaks narrow the valleys and cause choke points that would require tunneling to bypass. Miles of tunneling. All of that is very expensive, so you might consider that even with the 17.7 million mishap (I can't call it a mistake because there was no way of knowing) the chosen route was likely cheaper than more direct alternatives. Like the Seattle tunnel that was so expensive when it got stuck in granite no one knew was there, there was no other route, and the added costs were worth the result.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: Thanks for the links.  But your po-mo rif is so James Dodson.  No po-mo ever denied that people can and should agree on structures (ethical rules, institutions, etc.) for mutual benefit. But there is neither need nor justification for pretending metaphysical status for such structures.  They are created by human ingenuity, and human ignorance. 

This is scarcely a new idea. "Verum factum," as Giambattista Vico put it in the eighteenth century: the truth is made.  It is at the heart of the Enlightenment project, which is to destroy what might be called metaphysical abuse: positing that some quite obviously historical artifact, which always benefits someone at the cost of others, is actually carved in Being itself and therefore cannot be permitted to be questioned.  Metaphysical abuse is what gives mankind such wonderful things as god-emperors, churches with dungeons and racks, dehumanization of those lacking the right ancestry, and whole centuries of one-eyed and half-brained thinking.

Comment: Standard multiplication tables would cover up to 12x12.  That's for immediate recall.  However, the distributive property, which makes 23 x 412 quite a simple exercise, is part of the grade 5 curriculum.  I went to a math night for my kid when she was in grade 5 only to discover (a) kids were not being taught what they were supposed to be taught, and perhaps more alarming, (b) the majority of parents had expectations so low that living in a world where the most difficult math one might do in one's head should be limited to 12x12.    I taught my kid that night.  It took 10 minutes.   There is another point to be made, and that could be an article on its own, and that is that candidates for teacher's college not so long ago got in on the basis of their marks, and so young kids today are learning math from English and History majors who, for the most part, can't do grade 5 math.  Hence the problem.  There should be dedicated math teachers, just as there are language teachers.

Comment: We have a fundamental difference of belief. I disagree that no one is entitled to free health care (although this is not how I'd state it.) I think all citizens are entitled to public health care, as we are to public education, public safety, public libraries, and public lands. It's paid for through our collective taxes, not based on whether we use it, or can afford it, or meet someone's narrow definition of who is deserving. I bet I've paid for a service you used that I did not--did your kids attend public school? Have you ever called a cop, needed the fire department? Even if you answer no to all of those questions, there are places in your life where you or those you love rely on a safety net that is part of the liberal democracy the United States represents. (I use the term liberal in its historical sense, not the current political one, so don't get all up in arms.) I believe health care is part of this tapestry of rights and responsibilities, and I'm proud to fight for it.

Comment: Unfortunately you are wrong. This benefit also applies to fathers. 

One of my male employees received this benefit twice. He worked in a small group of employees in a government certified trade. The group was unionized & the union contract demanded that only certified people could perform the work. Their was a continually shortage of these certified employees looking for work. Hiring a temporary employee wasn't an alternative.

The guy was quite happy to live on a reduced income. He treated the whole thing as a joke. His fellow unionized employees hated it as the group would be short handed for the period.  

When we required a new long term employee for the unionized group we could bring in an unexperienced person working as an apprentice working at a reduced unionized wage scale with a multi year apprenticeship. The apprentice had to take annual formal class room training in a neighbouring city at his expense. The company was not allowed to provide the formal training at the jobsite

Comment: Displacing families typically only occurs when there is a chronic condition for which a specialist is not available, not in all cases and not acute cases. For example there is a primary LVAD coordinator in the region, but patients are still seen in Seattle regularly. This is a functional solution: 1 specialist to handle regular care working with a team out of a larger area that can support that team without significantly driving up costs for patients.
I do have family that require specialist care, and yes having care here is convenient, but a good team with communication can and has been established for my family even with outside specialists based in Seattle. We live in a highly connected world, telemedicine does work, anecdotal and empirical evidence both show it.

And again I note PAMC and ANMC have CEOs and have the highest paid CEOs, so your claim about the Regionals is unfounded.

Comment: The biggest issue which did get some mention in this article is the appointment of the Speaker. Obviously the NDP and Green Alliance would like the Liberals to step forward, as it would ensure that this Alliance would always have enough votes to pass legislation. There is little up side for the Liberals as you could be looking at a government that would serve out the 4 years. By refusing the NDP must nominate a Speaker which puts the seat count in a tie. The Speaker can break ties but to do it continually would be political suicide for the NDP. The bargaining point here for the Liberals is to gain some input on the legislation in exchange for not voting against it, and putting the Speaker and the NDP in an awkward position. The Greens would have to temper their demands as well as the NDP, and in effect you could have the House working together as three parties . My bet here is this is exactly what will happen, for a least a year or two, and then a new election.

Comment: Hello Rod ... Agreed. If you even suspect that the other person is not being honest (or if the other suspects that about you), then this poisons the well. However, there is still a problem EVEN IF each person is being as open and honest as possible. And this is that there is always some data being left out. No person can give out all past information and current thought (which sometimes changes even while speaking). Both the speaker and the recipient are continuously caught up in dealing with the inherent errors of communication. Bettering the communication (and resultant understanding) is a process of shaving away errors. This is also the process of science. It may take an active determination NOT to fall prey to the pitfalls of stereotyping and "needing" premature closure ... deciding you have "the answer" too soon.

Politicians uses slogans. Very little useful data ... often distorted data. Bettering America ... bettering humanity ... requires better communication. It can be done.

Comment: Hi Catou1403, 

Christa from Civil here. By default, you should receive notifications via email that someone has replied to your comment; maybe check your spam folder? 

You can also see your replies if you click on the "Activity" tab just to the right of the "Comments" tab, at the top of the comments section (it has a star icon next to it). There, you'll be able to see all of your comments. Each comment has a gray bar below it, where reply indications are shown. If you click on "Username replied to your comment", a new "Conversation" tab will open, showing your comment and all of its replies.

Our system is a bit different, and doesn't have a "follow" option (though it may, in the future).

You can show/hide all replies by clicking the "Hide replies" button at the top of the comments section, or you can show/hide replies on a single comment thread by clicking on the down-carat at the top left of the comment.

I hope this is helpful! More info is available at civil.helpscoutdocs.com

Comment: Taxes?  In "Indian country" neither the state or municipality can tax or regulate -- the tribe has tax and regulation authority.  In the Fairbanks borough 94 Native allotments exist--several within the city.  Any one of those could be relatively easily transferred to tribal ownership and become free of taxation and regulation -- think marijuana, the new "casino business"-- already approved by the Department of Justice for tribal activity.  Check it out on Google...   I agree with 9th Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Ferdinand Fernandez, who wrote in 1997 that recognition of Indian country in Alaska would create a "blizzard of litigation" as more than 200 tribes try to define the extent of their governmental powers.  "The litigation permutations are as vast as the capacity of fine human minds can make them", Fernandez wrote.

Comment: The average is the wrong measurement to use as it artificially skews the numbers downward, as if someone only worked for the government for 12 years, their numbers will be way lower than someone who worked 35 years. Comment: As others have noted here, the issue is complex, but as a fundamental tenet I think we could do worse than insisting that companies and people "use the courts to challenge the people or companies at the root cause of the alleged harm, rather than an expeditious third party." Information, or disinformation as the case may be, is best dealt with in the bright light of the public sphere. If that is ineffective, I would argue the light needs to be brighter, not dimmer. We have laws to deal with the stuff that causes harm, and when we don't then we need to discuss creating laws to fill those gaps. I realize that this discussion about restricting search results is itself, at its heart, about creating law, but it seems like the wrong place to focus. It's like using a chemical that is highly toxic to all forms of plant and animal life to get rid of one particular pest.

Comment: I love how the author is using a science basis to support her position. I love how many commenters are agreeing that science should be used to make decisions. However, even a cursory examination of the link provided [although I'm confident the author has many more, she is a trained phD in neuro], reads [from the authors of the paper] "The mechanisms by which sex differences in the mammalian brain arise are poorly understood,..." AND "Despite extensive investigation looking at the direct effects of chromosome complement4,5,6,7, gonadal hormones and epigenetic influences8,9,10,11,12 on the developing brain, there is a paucity of information that has addressed the multifaceted role of these factors on the progenitor cells that generate the central nervous system—neural stem cells (NSCs)." This is a reminder to all that stating "research shows.." is vague position. Extrapolating results from a model organism to the human condition is likely to mislead.

Comment: http://www.factcheck.org/2016/05/trump-distorts-clintons-gun-stance/
Trump Distorts Clinton’s Gun Stance
Clinton has a gun violence prevention proposal on her website, which would deny gun owners from buying certain guns and block or delay the ability of some to purchase guns. But it does not call for taking any guns away.
Among other things, her plan would:
Expand background checks. 
Close the so-called “Charleston Loophole.”
Ban semi-automatic “assault weapons.”
Clinton has said her gun proposals are “consistent with constitutional rights,” acknowledging that gun owners have a constitutional right to own guns.
Trump may choose not to believe what Clinton says, but the fact is there is no evidence that Clinton wants to “take your guns away” or “abolish the Second Amendment.” She hasn’t said that, and her gun proposals would not do that.

Comment: Much truth has been spoken here. Yet, I cannot help but feel sad & disheartened reading comments—even the ones with which, apart from the stereotypes & exaggerations, I might agree. Reason being—1 of the things that has set the UNITED STATES of AMERICA apart from other nations; &, some could argue, is why the country rose to such success & prominence is precisely because we had a common goal of keeping our nation together despite our differences. Plus, we have a Constitution that allows for people of all walks of life to live as equals (at least in principle). Those of us who've traveled the country & the globe know that a native New Yorker is as different from a native Texan as a Russian is from a Brazilian. In fact, we Coloradans know that even a Boulderite is as different from a Springsteen (is that really the demonym for people from CO Springs?) as a Parisian is from a Beijinger.   Yet, our nation has held together because we know we are stronger together even with our differences.

Comment: Nate, you are right, they are surprisingly small compared to military planes today.   Yet still awesome.  We were able to tour  a B-17 and other WWII planes when they were here some months ago.  For a kid who grew up during WWII as I did, just being up close to that Flying Fortress gave me goose bumps; watching it land made me think of  tattered, damaged bombers returning from a raid over Europe, barely making to a British airfield with an engine missing and wounded crew aboard.
And  they are so small inside, yet had a crew of 10  crammed in there, pity the poor guy rolled up in the ball turret--all of this in a windy non-heated, non-pressured thin-shelled cylinder at 40 degrees below zero at 25,000 feet.  And even with all those guns, the "Fortress" suffered heavy casualties over Europe unless protected by long-range fighters.
Hard for folks today to understand what America  was like when we were fighting for survival and most everyone felt involved.
They were our Greatest Generation.

Comment: Any program that allows yet another mountain of money to flow to colleges and universities must address the impact it will have on tuition increases. We know (but it is seldom acknowledged) that the tidal wave of student loans has enabled universities to raise tuition without impact on enrollment, and without significant pushback from the public. Worse, it has enabled the legislature to abdicate its responsibility to fund its public universities. We can expect more of the same from a free-tuition program unless strong controls are put in place to limit tuition increases. Absent these controls, we run the risk that a free-tuition program will eventually become a massive, unaffordable entitlement. We have already hamstrung an entire generation of Americans with student loan debt. We need to ensure that another program offering "free money" does not create yet another problem.

Comment: I have  great sympathy for anyone unjustly convicted of a crime.  However, many times eyewitness identification is the only identification you have.  I do agree law enforcement and our legal system in general should be required to do their utmost to gather as much exculpatory evidence as possible.  I do not agree that witnesses who have later proven to have made erroneous identifications should be be held criminally or civilly liable - if the errors were committed in good faith.  After all, who among us has never made a mistake?

Perhaps as much as is practical, all interviews between law enforcement personnel (and health care professionals working at their behest) and potential witnesses should be recorded for later review.  But even when written or otherwise archived records of interviews exist, we need to remain vigilant because shocking miscarriages of justice have still occurred.  Look up the McMartin Preschool travesty for one of the more egregious examples.

Comment: There is a point of diminishing returns on additional bike facilities.    There are those that will ride bicycles and those that will not.   In my age group among my friends I'm the only one who frequently rides.  Eugene is by no means devoid of bike lanes, off street paths, short cuts, and bike racks, but  bike use is still limited by weather,  fear of nighttime riding, ability to carry things,  distances to be covered with the time available.     I do not see a rental bike scheme greatly adding to the number of bike trips for these reasons.    Those that are prone to riding a bike already have a privately owned one and use it.   I would prefer to see a two year trial of the rental project and then a totally unbiased analysis of its effectiveness.   If it does not measure up to predetermined objective standards, discontinue it and reclaim as much of the taxpayers' contribution as possible.

Comment: Except.

Except the Gates drive, while it may have a nominally longer expected service life, will maroon you wherever you are if it breaks.

Except the Rohloff is so complicated that mechanics, even in Germany where the thing is made, won't touch it, so a $2000 wheel with a Rohloff Speedhub is a disposable.

The pinion drive is cool - Peter White in New Hampshire sells a line of German bikes with the thing - but again, what's the point exactly?  To make the bicycle, one of the simplest, most perfect mechanical devices in the history of mankind, so complicated that it can't be repaired?

The ultimate year round bike isn't ultimate at all - it's simple.  A frame with clearance for big fat tires carrying  low pressure (traction and shock absorption).  Made of steel (because aluminum bikes are like riding a truss).   Handlebars above the saddle height (so you can see where you're going), which is a matter of frame design.  Disk brakes (because icy rims are a b!t@h to stop with). 

Simple.

Comment: It is useful to recall that the original Canada-US Free Trade agreement (which was later folded into NAFTA when Mexico became a member) had as its cornerstone a commitment from Canada that we would sell our oil to the US at the same price as in our domestic market and that we would never give priority to domestic purchasers if supplies became tight.  

It would be a bit rich under these circumstances for the US to now put a tariff on Canadian oil imports.  It would also be contrary to US treaty obligations unless Canada agreed to the tariff or the US gave the requisite prior notice that it was withdrawing from NAFTA.

I'm really surprised to read and hear so many implicitly misleadeing reports of potential unilateral US tariff initiatives contrary to NAFTA without acknowledging that the US itself would have to forego the current benefits under NAFTA etc. in order to make such a change.

Comment: Rest assured, any Canadian citizen can think of a reason they might like to reopen the constitution.  I would personally like to see the Constitution reopened to reaffirm the superiority of individual rights, reaffirm absolute equality of individuals under the law and as our supreme societal value, remove all language pertaining to group rights and/or affirmative action, to establish that 'my family was here first' is not a reasonable argument to receive special rights/privileges and or demean other citizens/residents, and to establish once and for all that all Canadians are entitled to all the benefits and responsible for all the duties equally therein. However, I also recognize that other stakeholders/interest groups/provinces want to open the Constitution for entirely different reasons and that it is very unlikely we could achieve consensus on change at this time. That's just reality. Canadians currently do not see eye to eye regarding what direction this nation should be heading.

Comment: I now live in Alaska, in a small town on an island. From May through September we get cruise ships everyday plus people who fly in and spend a week or two. This year, our little town of 8,000 had over one million people come in by cruise ship!
Somedays, we had five or six ships, the total of passengers getting off the ships was over 10,000, more then our population.
The area I live in is rural but it was designated as a "tourism zone" because there were so many problems by tours,including people using our yards to relive themselves. 
Garbage was everywhere. So, the tour companies and taxis that brought people out here had to pay for permits,  register and have their employees take classes, and pay for portable potties and garbage removal. 
To enforce this, two people are hired for the season to check on the tours, issue violations, and make emergency calls for injured or ill people.
Put it back on to the people who are making the money off the tours, including the Farmer Market vendors

Comment: The way it works in other jurisdictions is that the records are kept, the lawyers get them through motions or discovery, the documents aren't entered, but the people who made the complaints are called as witnesses during the case, so that the judge and jury get to examine the credibility of the witnesses.  Opposing counsel may call the people who found the complaint to not be credible to respond.  Then the judge or jury can decide.  Usually, there are multiple complaints by multiple people over time who have no association with each other other than being unfortunate enough to have problems with the same officer.

Comment: Yes, but the manufacture of PV uses petroleum products or coal.  It also uses a lot of water.  So my big "thing" about solar is that 1) the sun don't always shine, 2) the sun don't always shine enough, 3) max lifetime of PV panels before replacement.  If maintained well, then can be prolonged use., 4) small market saturation, as was seen here in our islands...many startups, but now many endups, 5) and the biggest one is that it receives subsidization.  Just because it's subsidized won't always mean that it will be viable longterm.  And if it were already viable, it wouldn't need a subsidy.  Plus been around for a long time and still not ubiquitous.  But more power to (pun intended) the folks that choose for themselves this alternative.

As I do work around the Pacific, we often find that solutions for our area are not viable nor sustainable for some of the communities we work with.  Example:  Bangladesh.  They have naturally occurring arsenic underground all over the place.  (Cont.)

Comment: Not a digression really...
"In January 1984, Sr. Mary Margaret Funk, a Benedictine nun from Indiana, paid a visit to Maryknoll missionary nuns working in Bolivia. On what should have been a routine trip to the local town for a convocation ceremony, a flash flood swept away the jeep in which she, three nuns, a priest, and a disabled boy they had adopted were traveling. Only she and the priest survived." 
"What happened that night catapulted Sr. Meg into twenty-five years of prayer and self-examination. She relentlessly explored her relationship with the transcendent and immanent God, the profundities of her religious tradition, her commitment to spiritual practice, and her very human failings. It was a journey that left her spiritually naked before the terrible love of God; a journey to keep one’s heart open to the transforming wounds of suffering."  She prayed Psalms. Out loud. In crisis worse than cold water her heart overflowed with prayer.  Unceasing prayer is -- real.

Comment: Let's put aside your definition of "slave labour", which extends to low-wage labour in places where there are few income-earning opportunities. 

Slavery is not permitted under free-market capitalism, since it violates the principle of individual freedom. If there are countries in which such abuses occur, then blame that country's laws, its institutions or its corruption, and hold the companies involved responsible. They are not representative of free-market capitalism any more than companies that commit fraud are representative of free-market capitalism.

Besides, your evidence is entirely anecdotal. It does not negate the fact that poverty rates are in rapid decline, especially in countries that embrace free markets, free trade, sound institutions and the rule of law. 

And if you think your socialist utopia will prevent illegal behaviour, then you are irredeemably naïve. On the contrary, it cannot exist without violating individual freedom.

Comment: Follow the legal reasoning. Per the law, to use a firearm against another person, even just to threaten, is to use deadly force. Even if you don't actually fire, you have still used deadly force.

The use of deadly force in self-defense is only legally justified if the threat you are defending against is also a deadly force threat, armed or not. So, if you state you felt a deliberate shot to the leg (which can easily kill or maim regardless) was "sufficient" to stop a threat, almost by definition you did not feel that threat was actually serious enough to justify using the gun at all. If you didn't think the attack constituted a threat of death or grievous bodily harm, why were you shooting?

Firearms cannot, by law, be used as "less lethal" defensive weapons to ensure compliance or to counter non-lethal threats, regardless of your intent. If they aren't threatening your life, you don't even threaten with a gun, much less shoot. If they are, you shoot to stop, not to wound.

Comment: I was in a similar situation in Viet Nam. There was an upper middle aged soldier who as a teenager was married for less than a year, and divorced. He had tried for an annulment but was told he couldn't get one. He remarried. All while I knew him he went to mass but did not receive communion because the priest back home told him he couldn't. We talked about this a lot, but he still wouldn't receive. One evening on the eve of an operation, we all had mass together, and he received communion. It is good he did, because he did not fare well the next day.  

No doubt some would say he died in mortal sin. I am not one of them.

Comment: Great points! I don't, however, think technology is an essential part of a quality education. In fact, the over reliance and blind faith in technology as the panacea for a failing education system is a large part of the problem. Last I heard 4J's priority was an iPad for every student. What an incredible waste of money. Teachers like it because it shifts the burden of teaching and instruction on a piece of technology. 

When my kids went through school I was amazed at how little reading and writing they did, especially writing. 4J schools gave them very little, and at best random, instruction in grammar and punctuation. They read mostly contemporary fiction that focused on black and white issues of social justice rather than challenging works that made them think. 

There are charter schools all over the country giving a quality education to kids from underprivileged backgrounds, but the teachers' union and the status quo will keep those kids in the dark for the foreseeable future.

Comment: I have no particular interest in watching this. Kennedy's and Lincoln's assassinations had elements of unsolved mystery about them, and the Crucifixion is an inexhaustible subject for people of faith as well as history buffs. But the Reagan shooting? Horrible as it was, it seems to me a pretty straightforward crime story.

I will say this, though. I remember watching Al Haig's pompous comments to the press ("Constitutionally, gentlemen...") and thinking, even as he was speaking, how foolish he looked. Anybody who lived through Watergate should have known that the Speaker of the House was next in line for the presidency after the VP, and Haig had a front row seat during Nixon's final days in office.

Come to think of it, I hope Donald Trump doesn't see this movie. He's got a bigger ego than even Haig, and it might give him ideas.

.

.

.

.

Comment: Correct Tony, but it was not only the last time, it was the only time the only time the WHO tried to rank health care systems. Yes, the methodology and data was significant flawed. The WHO abandoned it.   

The WHO gave up trying to "rank" systems and now just tries to provide statistics by indicators. So if one actually Googles "World Heath Organization (WHO) 2016 Statistics", this is what you get:     http://www.who.int/gho/publications/world_health_statistics/2016/en/

This is a primarily a comparative report on health status, not health system. Certainly no ranking and the vast majority of the health status measures are not very strongly related to the health system, they reflect socio-economic conditions and status. 

All in all, when someone cites the WHO health system ranking, you know it is a person who knows nothing about health or health care systems.

Comment: I agree children should have sunscreen, ear protection & water, but the reasons you give for not bringing your children do not apply to a nursing infant. The presence of drunk & stoned fans will not make an impression on a baby. It's entirely possible that the sleep schedule of an infant actually fits fine with an evening game, and afternoon games are done by dinnertime, hardly a late hour for any child.

Nursing mothers & their babies are often more comfortable together than apart. The mother of your child can explain why. She can also enlighten you on why a mom who has no hungry baby available will welcome a private comfy spot to pump and still have a chance to use their season tickets. Yes, really.

I would not personally bring a child to an NFL stadium, but that's my decision. As long as someone protects their baby's skin and hearing, attends to physical needs &  doesn't allow them to disturb others, there's no reason to judge that decision or call them selfish.

Comment: Just because you have rigid expectations about gender doesn't mean that they are right or correct. 

I was a total tomboy as a child, long enough ago that we can't blame the current toxic environment for it, and thank god I had a mother and family that accepted me for who I was. I wasn't forced to wear stupid frilly dresses and play with stupid frilly dolls and stupid frilly girls. Instead hung out with my brother and his friends, climbed trees, etc, and was accepted as one of them. And while I had to endure a hell of a lot of teasing, that was probably more to do with my advanced vocabulary than my tomboyishness. 

I grew out of it, as will most boys and girls if they are accepted and loved, but if I hadn't, I know that my family would have still accepted me, and that family love and acceptance is what helped me overcome not only the horrible bullying I endured, but sexual assault, too. 

No amount of being forced to be a "girly girl" would have done that for me.

I don't think anyone is avoiding anything.  But to be clear, you suffer from flawed logic -->if you don't win the popular vote you can't win the presidency.  When in fact, the correct answer is you can only win the presidency if you win the electoral college.

Let me explain, CA and NY matter.  All 50 states matter.  All 3,000+ counties matter.  Each vote matters.  But the way they matter is based on the system (the electoral college) that says, "hey candidate, if want to be president you need to make sure you have support across a broad swath of America.  This is because, as the guardian of democracy, I want to make sure that vast majority of America is represented.  Therefore, I give you a cap on how much a particular place will count in the electoral college.  Go above that fine, but you need minimum support everywhere."

Good day sir or madam, whichever the case may be.

Comment: The National Popular Vote bill was approved in 2016 by a unanimous bipartisan House committee vote in both GA (16 electoral votes) and MO (10).
Since 2006, the bill has passed 35 state legislative chambers in 23 rural, small, medium, large, Democratic, Republican and purple states with 261 electoral votes, including one house in Arizona (11), Arkansas (6), Connecticut (7), Delaware (3), The District of Columbia, Maine (4), Michigan (16), Nevada (6), North Carolina (15), Oklahoma (7), and Oregon (7), and both houses in California, Colorado (9), Hawaii, Illinois, New Jersey, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Mexico (5), New York, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Washington. 

It changes state winner-take-all laws (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), to guarantee the presidency to the candidate with the most national popular votes, without changing anything in the Constitution, using the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes.

Comment: The "spirit" of Alaska is death. Kill, kill, kill, as though killing is some sort of sacred activity.  People complain about violent crime, and want to link it to everything but the ugly truth. 
When a culture venerates violence - hunting, trapping, fishing, etc. - it's really venerating violence and death by violence. Teach a child to hunt, to shoot, to fish and you are teaching that child that violence is okay, no different than abusing a child teaches him or her that abuse is okay.  As for so-called "sport" hunting goes: As Bill Mahr says, "is it really a sport if one side doesn't know it's in the game?"
The link between killing animals and killing people is well established. 
People are going to whine and complain about traditional values and how hunting and fishing have always been a part of Alaskan "culture."  That doesn't make it morally and/or ethically right.  War has always been a part of the human culture too. It's time we got a clue. Violence begets violence.

Comment: Until 2002, the U.S. courts had declared that the Constitution's Second Amendment did not provide any individual right for citizens to own firearms. Rather, it meant what its text clearly states: that firearms shall be held by "the People" – a collective, not individual right – insofar as they are in the service of "a well-regulated militia."
For 218 years, judges concluded that the amendment authorized states to form militias, what is now called the National Guard, and did not contain any individual right to own firearms.
Warren Burger, the arch-conservative Supreme Court justice appointed by Richard Nixon, described the idea of an individual right to bear arms as "one of the greatest pieces of fraud on the American public by special interest groups that I have ever seen in my lifetime."
It wasn't until 2008, in a reversal of all earlier precedents, the Supreme Court ruled that there is an individual right to own weapons. The decision was written by Antonin Scalia.

Comment: Your response clearly indicates you have never operated a small business with such a simplistic response.  Compensation expense is not the only item that is effected by a wage increase. You have to factor the other expenses that will increase proportionally as a result. If  minimum wage increases, then so do a variety of inputs to someone's business including raw materials, inventory, insurance, advertising, etc. Because your suppliers will pass on their increased costs to you! This is above and beyond taxes, utilities, and rent that need to be paid. I assure you many small businesses will feel the impact of this increase, and it's not a matter of $28.80 over the long-run, it's much more. It will become much harder for independent stores to grow as a result of this decision. The outcome will  result in less business investment, less youth employment, and less choice because independent shops will be the first wave of businesses to be hit by this disastrous policy.

Comment: It's not so much that the humanities have drifted into ridiculous subject matter as that the humanities have abandoned themselves. The occasional ridiculous subject matter is just a symptom. Part of what's left of the humanities has already migrated toward the social sciences. Many of the central categories of humanistic study now come from sociology. Some of the rest will migrate toward the other sciences, toward empirical studies of various sorts. The study of human animals will belong to biology and chemistry and psychology. The activist programs that have bedded down in the humanities can migrate toward ethnic and gender studies, disability studies, sexuality studies, and other social sciences--and they can thrive and do their work there. The residual humanities might continue for a long time as a feature of some kinds of institutions, but they will continue to lose legitimacy, if not appeal. They have produced the causes of their own decline.

Comment: "Too shallow" describes the article as well as Vancouver harbour. The issue is not the harbour, it is how tankers will transit the perilous passages between the Southern Gulf Islands. Some of the tortuous channel is less than 1km wide with strong currents, reefs, heavy marine traffic and an ill- marked route.. And you can't clean up a bitumen spill - the bitumen is on the ocean floor (that's why the oil sands are where they are), smothering and killing everything there for centuries.

Comment: The only reason firefighters are first responders to medical issues, is that they are usually available to do so. There are not enough fires and car accidents and industrial spills in a day. So we have this well paid resource utilized to respond quickly to help out, because our system of paramedic response is not timely enough, or available enough, to get there as fast.

To have a fast paramedic response to rival that of our firefighters, means that we have to provide staffing levels so that there is a quicker response team on hand.  Ideal system meet taxpayer response.

My family has utilized the 911 system several times over the years, a seizure, 2 strokes, an aneurysm, and a heart attack..  All five times firefighters have responded first, and within minutes.  I know they are not paramedics, but what price their fast first aid response, comfort, and guidance.  Compared to waiting the additional 10-15 minutes for an ambulance.

Comment: Respectfully, there are a great many people who identify as "Indigenous," and most certainly have the provable roots, but cannot claim any specific nation. Some were disenfranchised by the government; others were disenfranchised by their own people for one reason or another.

That does not make those people less Indigenous. It just makes them stateless, and honestly, your comment is precisely why this kind of social violence continues to take place, both against and among Indigenous peoples.

Ethnic nationalism is highly toxic. The worst thing that could happen--and it has, and still is happening--is that Indigenous communities adopt the concepts of the oppressor. Prior to colonization, Indigenous identities were highly fluid. This idea that one had to be a documented member of a band is new, and a reflection of colonial attitudes.

Comment: "I think that is the purpose of the system."
I have to ask you how you came to that conclusion.  I'm always looking to expand my political history to include new information and I cannot think of anything that framers of the constitution wrote or did that lends support to this conclusion.  If anything, the reverse seems more likely with events like Marbury v. Madison.  A case which illustrated that the US was a "nation of laws."

The Senate has a legal duty to advice certain Presidential actions.  The reason why we have only one office in the Executive is for swift action.  Other executive actions are open to disagreement, such as treaties and use of the military, and not even holding a hearing for any of them is a gross dereliction of duty.

I'd say it is fair to conclude the Republican led Senate undermined the process.  Putting the good of the party before upholding the law and the Constitution "undermined the process."

Over the past several years, some of my colleagues have transitioned from DougCo to neighboring districts, and all have reported that they would be getting significant pay increases.

I never said teachers were near the poverty line. However, you seem to think that anything above the poverty line is fair pay for college-educated, seasoned professionals who will be responsible for preparing kids for the future.

I believe that a decent starting salary for a secondary school educator in Colorado is around $50,000. After 5-7 years of experience, secondary teachers should be making more than $60,000. That's actually quite cheap for what we do.

Comment: Lyme disease is fortunately rare in Oregon. What are not rare, however, are quacks who do not believe in science.  

Real lyme disease is treatable with a short course of antibiotics, even if caught late. After treatment, the infection has been wiped out, so there is no treatment other than time for any lingering symptoms. Lyme testing is also very accurate a few weeks after infection. 

There is a strong scientific consensus regarding the diagnosis and treatment of lyme disease, but "chronic lyme" has become a popular fake diagnosis with the help of shady labs and alternative medicine quacks, called "lyme literate". Vocal groups like Oregon Lyme Disease Network promote pseudoscience, conspiracy theories, and quackery. They also tell sad stories that often do not stand up to scrutiny since they contradict known science. 

We should empathize with Lyme Truthers but not feed their delusion. We should also protect the public from the snake oil salesmen who prey on the innocent.

Comment: Protests aren't necessarily hate. That's just bizarre. Protesting is a constitutional right (you know, that first amendment?). And protesting is not the same thing as destroying property. Sure, people have a right to their feelings - but you have to admit that there's a problem when somebody's hate revolves around efforts to deny equal standing to others whom he/she sees as fundamentally lesser, such as neo-Nazis or white supremacists. Personally, I don't think such hate should be criminalized, but it absolutely should be excoriated, loud and clear. Because that's not the America I want to live in. 

Finally, though violence is always wrong, in terms of message there is no comparison between antifa and white supremacists. Anita is against fascism - ethnic cleansing, blood and soil, etc. White supremacists and neo-Nazis are by definition hateful and exclusionary. They're not even remotely comparable.

Going by your example of 10K in London. London has a population of approximately 8.5 million and 10K of that is one tenth of one percent of the population of the city as a whole. Unless all Syrian expats go to London for months on end, it won't make a huge dent in the demographics.

According to an article appearing in a 2015 issue of the Guardian, London's population increased by 900K or 12% since 2001. That means London was naturally growing by about .85% per year. So at the end of the day 10K is about 1/8th of the annual average population growth in London. Granted some of these people may be in need of immediate assistance, but long term is more important as the short term won't break the bank.

Comment: How about this reference from the Department of Health and Human services?  https://www.acf.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/opre/head_start_executive_summary.pdf

"In summary, there were initial positive impacts from having access to Head Start, but by the end of 3rd grade there were very few impacts found for either cohort in any of the four domains of cognitive, social-emotional, health and parenting practices. The few impacts that were found did not show a clear pattern of favorable or unfavorable impacts for children."

Wiliki's concern about the control group is valid. However, in light of this finding and others like it, I think the burden is on the supporters of Head Start and similar programs to show that free preschool is a worthwhile investment. With limited dollars, we must be sure we are spending them where it makes a difference.

Comment: Levels of classification for American Intelligence 
Confidential: Information that reasonably could be expected to cause damage to the national security if disclosed to unauthorised sources. Most military personnelhave this level of clearance. 

Secret: The same wording in the first sentence above, except it substitutes serious damage. 

Top Secret: Again, the same wording except to substitute exceptionally grave damage. 

Codeword: Adds a second level of clearance to Top Secret,so that only those cleared with the codeword can see it. Administered by the CIA. The material discussed by Mr Trump with the Russians was under a codeword, sources told the Washington Post.

Comment: Reducing Alaska health insurance costs by “allowing companies to sell insurance across state lines” is the biggest con perpetuated by Republicans. The biggest factor in preventing health insurance companies from doing this now, is the insurance companies own business decision based on profit, NOT to do business in Alaska, due to our high cost of delivering health services in the state. Any out of state company that ultimately decides to sell insurance in our state will ALWAYS CONTINUE to rate an Alaskan resident's premium based upon the health care delivery costs in Alaska. 

Single payer, universal care is the only system that can ultimately reform these geographically diverse areas into a unified system of cost sharing marketing & administration expenses while providing an alternative competing plan to private insurance.

Comment: "Sunshine Law, which requires government meetings to be open to the public except in the rarest of circumstances." Misleading. Comment: I'm not big on raising taxes, but I can see with my own eyes the continued deterioration of city maintained streets.  I think the per gallon tax is preferable to another add-on to the property taxes.  I do have some control over how much gas I use, I have no control over that 3% increase in my assessed property value every year.  Just to be clear, the proposal is 3 cents per gallon.  If gas is $2/gallon, the additional tax would be 1.5%.  If gas gets back up to $4/gallon (which it may thanks to the carbon neutral bs passed by the legislature last year) the 3 cents per gallon would only be an additional .75% of the cost.  Every little bit count, but somethings have to get paid for.  I will be looking for the city to put in place some sort of tracking and reporting mechanism to show that the new collections are going to asphalt, not to more city employees.

Comment: I don't intend to defend the authoritarian aspects of Castro's regime, nor the obvious poverty that I witnessed during a trip around Cuba last year.  But...I suggest that the author should have considered the alternative.  A quick stroll through the UN Development Index shows Cuba to be ahead of its neighbours in virtually every development index: education, lifespan, infant mortality, violent crime rate, etc. All this in the face of a US blockade.  Now, I absolutely accept that most people in Cuba want more freedom - we heard that time and again during our travels. Further, average incomes are very low.  However, the hard numbers (i.e not soft, hippy, rose-coloured glasses sentiment) show that, on many of the indicators that matter, Cuba comes out looking pretty good.  No, not compared to the US or Canada, but compared to neighbours such as Mexico, Costa Rica, Honduras, Jamaica, Nicaragua, etc.

Comment: Quietly nestled among the risks to the project listed in the prospectus is the detailed route approval process and the fact that the Trans Mountain Expansion Project does not have an approved route. Kinder Morgan Canada President Ian Anderson said in the company's final investment press release that "our approvals are in hand and we are now ready to commence construction activities this fall" when the facts tell a very different story. The 157 NEB conditions on the project remain to be met, and the route approval process has been delayed over a month by the company's mismanagement of their responsibilities in it. About 400 statements of opposition to the route have been filed with the NEB thus far, and in all likelihood segments of the route will be rejected by the NEB when route hearings conclude. A shame that people who buy shares in the IPO will learn too late how wildly premature Anderson's statements were.

Comment: Agree. As a southern-raised conservative Christian who believes that God made all of us equal in our humanity, I find it very easy to understand why blacks would be deeply offended to see the Confederate flag.  Its defenders say it doesn't stand for racism, by those who fly it are not especially marked by their passion for equality, are they?  They say it stands for a noble cause --- resistance to Northern Aggression and the Right to Secession.  But what was the cause of that cause?  Slavery. It's meaning is clear enough, and it offends.  Agnikan is right:   If this flag DOESN'T offend you, you need a history and an ethics lesson.  And a lesson in basic Christianity and the meaning of empathy.

Comment: July 4 is a triple holiday for Hawaii -- 1776, 1894, 1960 (including some internet links to important documents of the Republic of Hawaii, and district-by-district official results of the statehood vote of 1959 where 94.3% of voters said yes to statehood)
http://tinyurl.com/68u7nz

July 4, 1894 marked the creation of the Republic of Hawaii through the publication of its Constitution. At least five delegates to the Constitutional Convention were native Hawaiians; the Constitution was published in both English and Hawaiian; the Speaker of the House was former royalist John Kaulukou. 

The Republic was internationally recognized. Formal letters of recognition were rediscovered in our state archives during February and March, 2008. They had been sent to President Sanford Dole, personally signed by Emperors, Kings, Queens, and Presidents of at least 20 nations, on four continents, in eleven languages. Photographs of the originals are linked at
http://tinyurl.com/jtecmvo

Comment: David, sorry, but the $16 Trillion of personal income is not applicable here.  Personal Income includes Social Security, SSI, and other benefits provided by government and other sources. Comment: Quote from the article:  Among the misconceptions about Pidgin, said Darrell H.Y. Lum, a panel speaker and the co-founder of Bamboo Ridge Press, is that it is “broken English” or a “language of the stupid.”  I've lived in Hawaii for 60 years, grew up in Hilo, learned pidgin for casual conversation among local friends, am part-Hawaiian, dropped my Southern drawl, and became an English teacher and librarian.  In all those years, I have never heard anyone describe pidgin as broken or for the stupid.  I've known people who were fascinated and intrigued by it but never considered it broken or the people who spoke it stupid.  Using pidgin to communicate in certain circumstances and contexts is one thing.  Yes, there IS a time and place for it.  Teaching students to speak it in public schools?  When hell freezes over and pigs fly.  Fix the current problems with public schools before creating another one.

Comment: "Free speech for student journalists reporting in school newspapers would be protected under legislation sponsored by Sen. Joe Fain, which passed the Senate on Thursday."

For those that have never read or studied the US Federal Constitution, here is a quick lesson. Free speech is the first right listed in the bill of rights. Rights are inherent to every living thing, and therefore by definition cannot be legislated. Its why the founders were careful to use the word enumerate in the bill of rights, as to use any other language might make the reader presume that rights are given to us by our constitution and our founders, and they are not. To attempt to legislate a right would mean that to be not a right but a privilege, and with that restrictions to follow, which this article was quick to reference.  "Under the “New Voices Act” legislation, student editors would be responsible for content".  Now go and read the bill and you will quickly understand why rights should never be legislated.
